AVLN_RISKS.long_description: The avalanche risk index score includes three components: an avalanche risk component, a consequence enhancing component (social vulnerability), and a consequence reduction component (community resilience).
AVLN_RISKS.long_name: Avalanche - Hazard Type Risk Index Score
AVLN_RISKS.short_description: The avalanche risk index score is a unitless index (0 minimum risk, 100 maximum risk) calculated to measure a community’s risk from an avalanche.

sources.name: Federal Emergency Management Agency: National Risk Index

AVLN_RISKS.statement: {features.name} has a avalanche risk index value of {value} where 0 is the minimum and 100 is the maximum.

Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

OZONE.statement: The summer daily average concentration of Ozone in an 8-hour period in {features.name} is {value}.

PM25.short_description: PM 2.5 levels in air, µg/m3 annual average
PM25.statement: The annual average concentration of Particulate Matter 2.5 in air in {features.name} is {value}.

PNPL.long_description: The superfund proximity index is the total count of sites proposed and listed on the NPL in each block group within 5 km of the average resident in a block group, divided by distance, calculated as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PNPL.long_name: Proximity to Superfund (National Priorities List (NPL)) sites
PNPL.short_description: Count of proposed or listed NPL - also known as superfund - sites within 5 km (or nearest one beyond 5 km), each divided by distance in kilometers
PNPL.statement: The Superfund Proximity Index in {features.name} is {value}.

PNPL_QRT.long_description: The superfund proximity index is the total count of sites proposed and listed on the NPL in each block group within 5 km of the average resident in a block group, divided by distance, calculated as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PNPL_QRT.long_name: Proximity to Superfund (National Priorities List (NPL)) sites
PNPL_QRT.short_description: Count of proposed or listed NPL - also known as superfund - sites within 5 km (or nearest one beyond 5 km), each divided by distance in kilometers
PNPL_QRT.statement: In {features.name} the Superfund Proximity Index is in the {value} quartile (National Capital Region quartiles).

PRE1960.long_description: The age of housing stock serves as a proxy for potential lead exposure based on regulations banning residential lead-based paint that went into effect in 1978.
PRE1960.long_name: Number of occupied housing units built pre-1960
PRE1960.short_description: Number of occupied of housing units built pre-1960, as an indicator of potential lead paint exposure
PRE1960.statement: The number of pre-1960 occupied housing units in {features.name} is {value}.

PRMP.long_description: The RMP facility proximity is the total count of RMP facilities in each block group within 5 km of the average resident in a block group, divided by distance, calculated as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PRMP.long_name: Proximity to Risk Management Plan (RMP) Facilities Index
PRMP.short_description: Count of RMP facilities (facilities that use extremely hazardous substances) within 5 km (or nearest one beyond 5 km), each divided by distance in kilometers
PRMP.statement: The Risk Management Plan Facility Proximity Index in {features.name} is {value}.

PRMP_QRT.long_description: The RMP facility proximity is the total count of RMP facilities in each block group within 5 km of the average resident in a block group, divided by distance, calculated as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PRMP_QRT.long_name: Proximity to Risk Management Plan (RMP) Facilities Index
PRMP_QRT.short_description: Count of RMP facilities (facilities that use extremely hazardous substances) within 5 km (or nearest one beyond 5 km), each divided by distance in kilometers
PRMP_QRT.statement: In {features.name} the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Facilities Index is in the {value} quartile (National Capital Region quartiles).

PTRAF.long_description: Residential proximity to traffic has been associated with various health impacts: asthma exacerbation and possibly onset and mortality; prevalence of coronary vascular disease as well as mortality; and coronary heart disease.
PTRAF.short_description: Count of vehicles (avg. annual daily traffic) at major roads within 500 meters, divided by distance in meters.
PTRAF.statement: The Traffic Proximity Index in {features.name} is {value}.

PTRAF_QRT.long_description: Residential proximity to traffic has been associated with various health impacts: asthma exacerbation and possibly onset and mortality; prevalence of coronary vascular disease as well as mortality; and coronary heart disease.
PTRAF_QRT.short_description: Count of vehicles (avg. annual daily traffic) at major roads within 500 meters, divided by distance in meters.
PTRAF_QRT.statement: In {features.name} the Traffic Proximity Index is in the {value} quartile (National Capital Region quartiles).

PTSDF.long_description: The hazardous waste proximity indicator is the total count of hazardous waste facilities in each block group within 5 km of the average resident in a block group, divided by distance, calculated as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PTSDF.long_name: Proximity to Treatment Storage and Disposal (TSDF) and Large Quanity Generators (LQG) Facilities Index
PTSDF.short_description: Count of hazardous waste facilities (TSDFs and LQGs) within 5 km (or nearest beyond 5 km), each divided by distance in kilometers
PTSDF.statement: The Hazardous Waste Proximity Index in {features.name} is {value}.

PTSDF_QRT.long_description: The hazardous waste proximity indicator is the total count of hazardous waste facilities in each block group within 5 km of the average resident in a block group, divided by distance, calculated as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PTSDF_QRT.long_name: Proximity to Treatment Storage and Disposal (TSDF) and Large Quanity Generators (LQG) Facilities Index
PTSDF_QRT.short_description: Count of hazardous waste facilities (TSDFs and LQGs) within 5 km (or nearest beyond 5 km), each divided by distance in kilometers
PTSDF_QRT.statement: In {features.name} the Hazardous Waste Proximity Index is in the {value} quartile (National Capital Region quartiles).

PWDIS.long_description: The wastewater discharge indicator quantifies a block group’s relative risk of exposure to pollutants in water bodies. This is achieved using toxicity-weighted concentrations in stream reach segments within 500 meters of a block centroid, divided by distance in meters, presented as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PWDIS.long_name: Index for major direct dischargers to water
PWDIS.short_description: Risk-Screening Environmental Indicator (RSEI) modeled toxic concentrations at stream segments within 500 meters, divided by distance in kilometers
PWDIS.statement: The relative risk from Wastewater Discharge in {features.name} is {value}.

PWDIS_QRT.long_description: The wastewater discharge indicator quantifies a census tract’s relative risk of exposure to pollutants in water bodies. This is achieved using toxicity-weighted concentrations in stream reach segments within 500 meters of a block centroid, divided by distance in meters, presented as the population-weighted average of blocks in each block group.
PWDIS_QRT.long_name: Index for major direct dischargers to water
PWDIS_QRT.short_description: Risk-Screening Environmental Indicator (RSEI) modeled toxic concentrations at stream segments within 500 meters, divided by distance in kilometers
PWDIS_QRT.statement: In {features.name} the Wastewater Discharge Proximity Risk Index is in the {value} quartile (National Capital Region quartiles).

RESP.long_description: The air toxics respiratory hazard index (HI) indicator is the respiratory HI from the analyzed carcinogens in ambient outdoor air, as provided by the 2017 Air Toxics Data Update.
RESP.short_description: Ratio of exposure concentration to health-based reference concentration
RESP.statement: The Air Toxics Respiratory Hazard Index in {features.name} is {value}, where values less or equal to 1 are not likely to result in noncancer adverse effects.

RFLD_RISKS.long_description: The riverine flood risk index score includes three components: a riverine flood risk component, a consequence enhancing component (social vulnerability), and a consequence reduction component (community resilience).
RFLD_RISKS.long_name: Riverine Flood - Hazard Type Risk Index Score
RFLD_RISKS.short_description: The riverine flood risk index score is a unitless index (0 minimum risk, 100 maximum risk) calculated to measure a community’s risk from riverine flood.

sources.name: Federal Emergency Management Agency: National Risk Index

RFLD_RISKS.statement: {features.name} has a riverine flood risk index value of {value} where 0 is the minimum and 100 is the maximum.

RISK_SCORE.long_description: In the NRI, the score includes three components: a natural hazards risk component, a consequence enhancing component (social vulnerability), and a consequence reduction component (community resilience).
RISK_SCORE.short_description: The NRI score is a unitless index (0 minimum risk, 100 maximum risk) calculated to measure a community’s risk to all 18 hazard types.

sources.name: Federal Emergency Management Agency: National Risk Index

RISK_SCORE.statement: {features.name} has a risk index value of {value} where 0 is the minimum and 100 is the maximum.

adequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequate.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate
adequate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

adequate.statement: There are {value} cases rated as adequate in {features.name}.

adequate_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving adequate prenatal care.  Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequate_pc.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate
adequate_pc.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

adequate_pc.statement: {value} of the cases in {features.name} rated as adequate.

adequateplus.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate plus.  Adequate Plus  prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is  110% or more. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
adequateplus.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate Plus

average_years_schooling.long_description: The Education Index measures the average education level achieved by the adult population in an area. This is based on the average years of schooling in an area. The calculation used to calculate the index can be found in (Bennett, D.L. Educational Inequailty in the United States: Methodology and Historical Estimates of Education Gini Coefficients. Econ. Modeling Microeconom. Stud. Health 2001). Higher educational attainment has been shown to have positive impacts on economic earning and positive health outcomes.

daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.

gini_index.long_description: The Gini Index is a summary measure of income inequality. The Gini coefficient incorporates the detailed shares data into a single statistic, which summarizes the dispersion of income across the entire income distribution. The Gini coefficient ranges from 0, indicating perfect equality (where everyone receives an equal share), to 1, perfect inequality (where only one recipient or group of recipients receives all the income). The Gini is based on the difference between the Lorenz curve (the observed cumulative income distribution) and the notion of a perfectly equal income distribution.

health_opportunity_indicator.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.

inadequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

inadequate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate

number_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households
number_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

obgyn_2sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
obgyn_2sfca.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
obgyn_2sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers

obgyn_3sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. percent_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the percent of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
percent_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households
percent_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
percent_food_insecure.statement: {value} percent of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

primcare_2sfca.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. schools_2year_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
schools_2year_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.

sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics
sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics

schools_2year_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

schools_2year_per_100k.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_per_100k.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.

sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics
sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
